Second stack.Although b-decay of 113mCd populates 113mIn with aratio of 0.14% and a half life of 14.1 y thecontribution of this process is negligible.
Second stack.Includes the cross section for 116m2In formation inaddition to that of 116m1In.
Second stack.111mCd is practically not populated through the decayof the simultaneously produced 111In and 111Ag.

M.free_text: Decay of 115Ag is negligible in this energy region.
Second stack.No cumulative processes take place because 117Ag cannotbe produced in a deuteron irradiation on a cadmiumtarget and the metastable state does not decay intothe ground state.

0.free_text: Includes the contributions from the decay of 105In (ground and metastable states), 105Cd and from theisomeric transition of the short-lived 105mAg inaddition to the direct formation cross section of105gAg.
Second stack.Contains the contribution from almost total (99.3% IT)decay of the isomeric state 111mAg and from the decayof 111Pd but the latter is negligible in this energyregion.

free_txt: The measured experimental data were compared to
those found in the literature.
The measured experimental data were compared to
and analyzed with theoretical calculations based on
the code ALICE-IPPE.
On the basis of the new experimental cross
sections integral yields were calculated.
In the case of the second stack the two sets of monitor
cross section values (Cu and Fe) cannot be fitted at
the same time to the recommended excitation functions.
For lack of a good explanation for this behavior it was
decided to rely on the Fe monitor because then the new
cross sections measured in the two experiments agree
well in the overlapping energy region.
Decay data were taken from WWW Table of Radioactive
Isotopes by L.P.Ekstrom and R.B.Firestone,
database version: 2/28/99.
The uncertainty on the energy of the
bombarding beam in the middle of each irradiated foil
was estimated by combining the uncertainties of the
energy degradation which depend on the thickness of the
target foils in the stack and the energy straggling.
The total uncertainty was obtained as positive
square root of a sum of the contributing sources of
errors in quadrature form, namely the errors in:
* the number of bombarding particles (7%),
* the number of target nuclei (3%),
* decay data (3%),
* detector efficiency (5%) and
* peak area (1-10%).
(ERR-1) Error in the number of bombarding
particles (7%),
(ERR-2) Error in  the number of target nuclei (3%),
(ERR-3) Error in  decay data (3%),
(ERR-4) Error in  detector efficiency (5%)
First stack.
Second stack.
First stack: Cd, Ag, Pt, Ir, Cu and Al foils,
second stack: Cd, Cu and Fe foils.
Primary deuteron energies: 40 MeV and 21 MeV,
beam intensities: 128 and 159 nA,
irradiation time: 0.45 and 1.00 hours, respectively.
In the case of the first stack counting started about
23 h after the end of the bombardment because of the
high radiation dose, so the information regarding the
short-lived radioisotopes was lost.
The recoil effect was found to be negligible.
The possible effect of secondary neutrons was checked
by placing extra target foils at the end of the stack
exposed only to neutrons, possibly generated in the
nuclear reactions. No activity was measured in these
last foils.
As the number of secondary protons is of the same order
as the number of secondary neutrons and the effect of
the latter was negligible, the effect of secondary
protons was also considered to be negligible.
Nondestructive measurement without chemical separation.
Chapter 4
Al: 25 micron, Fe: 9.5 micron, Cu: 7.61 micron.
The median deuteron energy in the successive target
foils was determined from the bombarding energy, the
stack composition and the foil thickness by
calculations on the basis of Andersen and Ziegler and
was corrected on the basis of the simultaneously
re-measured excitation function of the monitor
reactions.
Natural cadmium foils, thickness: 15.56 micron.
Data were taken from Table 2 of the ref.
The ground state was identified by its independent
gamma line (875.5 keV), while the cross section of the
metastable state was calculated by separation of the
line at 633 keV which is common with the ground state.
Data were taken from Table 2 of the ref.

obtained after separating the contribution of the
ground state from the common 657.8 keV gamma line.
